PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS (PHA)
The AES Alamitos RMP program includes a process to ensure that hazards associated with the aqueous ammonia SCR system are identified and controlled.  Within this program, before any not-in-kind changes are implemented for the SCR system, the process change is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate safeguards are in place to manage these hazards.  This process was also used as part of the 2001 addition of the Units 1-4 SCR systems.

The AES Alamitos primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations. HAZOP analysis in recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques. A team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise conducts the analyses. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well accident prevention and mitigation measures. The team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.  The last review of the hazards analysis was performed as part of this RMP resubmittal in May 2004.

The PHA teams findings are forwarded to facility management for resolution. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. The ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention. All approved mitigation options are tracked until they are completed. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from original design safety features, AES Alamitos, as part of the five year resubmittal process,  reviews (and if necessary) updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  Documentation of all PHA

s conducted are maintained for inspection at the facility.

OPERATING PROCEDURES
The AES Alamitos facility maintain written procedures that address various modes of SCR system (including storage tanks) operations.  These procedures generally include:

¿ Unit start up (boiler and flue gas blower) and operation;
¿ SCR system normal start-up, normal shut down and emergency shutdown;
¿ SCR system on-line operational procedures;
¿ Aqueous ammonia ordering and truck unloading procedure.

Other AES Alamitos procedures potentially impact the operation of the SCR system and storage tanks, but are not directly related to SCR system or tank operations. These include general safety and fire protection policies, procedures and practices. The SCR system¿s general operation and maintenance is governed by these policies and practices where they apply.

These operational procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are periodically reviewed to assure they are current and accurate.  The last major review of operational procedures occurred in October 2002, with an informal review as part of the RMP resubmittal process in May 2004.  The procedures are kept current and accurate by annotating/revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through an informal management of change process.  The facility maintains several master sets of operational and maintenance procedures ¿ including a set in the relevant control room, and truck unloading procedures at each ammonia storage tank unloading area.

TRAINING
To complement the written procedures for process operations, AES Alamitos has implemented a training program for all employees involved in operating or maintaining the SCR systems.  As an integral part of the safety and hazardous materials training, training which includes the safe receiving, operation and maintenance of the SCR system and associated tanks is provided to all personnel who

are or may be working with the SCR system and/or aqueous ammonia.  This training is accomplished utilizing resources available inside and outside the station.  All current facility employees have been operating and maintaining the SCR systems since they were first designed and constructed.  In general, new employees receive basic training in plant operations if they not already familiar with such operations and all new workers working with the SCR system or associated tanks are trained in the SCR system operating procedures as well as the specific hazards of ammonia.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with an experienced operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  After operators demonstrate (e.g. through tests, skills demonstration, etc.) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. 

The specific individual training programs at AES Alamitos is supported by the facility¿s Injury and Illness Prevention Program (IIPP) and written safety procedures manual, which emphasizes communication of safety hazards and requirements on a continuous basis, as well as general safety and safe work practices training.  As noted elsewhere in the RMP, hazardous materials emergency response training is also provided.  Training documentation is maintained by the facility.  

The SCR system and other safety training at AES Alamitos may be performed in various formats and environments ¿ including classroom, field-based, on-the-job, safety meeting, team meeting and informal `one-off¿ type interactions.  In addition, the facility¿s current aqueous ammonia vendor implements its own training program for their employees (including drivers) and assists in conducting biennial refresher training at AES for truck delivery and unloading procedures. 

Initial SCR system operational and maintenance training was conducted for all station operations, maintenance and engineering personn

el at the time each SCR system was constructed/installed as an integral part of each system¿s initial system start up and performance evaluation.  The training was conducted/supervised by the SCR system manufacturer/design company.  The training was both formal classroom-based and field-based.  A separate RMP program implementation training class was conducted in 1999 detailing the management and compliance requirements and responsibilities of the RMP/CalARP program.

In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures and hazards to ensure their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted as an integral part of the AES Alamitos¿ ongoing safety training program, but is assured met at least every 3 years.   At AES Alamitos, recent periodic refresher training has included the hazards of ammonia, ammonia truck delivery, loading and emergency procedures, off site consequences, general emergency response, and SCR system maintenance.  Refresher training was last conducted in February 2004.  The SCR system and RMP compliance is an element of the facility¿s annual environmental compliance training, last conducted in March 2004.

As an integral part of the Process Safety Information and Operating Procedures elements of the RMP, should the safety information or procedures be modified in any significant fashion, refresher training will be conducted.  

As part of the RMP submission, pursuant to 40 CFR 68.54(a) and 19 CCR 2755.4(a), AES Alamitos is hereby certifying that AES employees have the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities as provided in the operating procedures. 



MAINTENANCE
AES Alamitos has established practices and procedures to maintain facility systems and controls, including those associated with the aqueous ammonia SCR systems and storage tanks.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting traini

ng, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, and (4) correcting identified deficiencies.  In combination, these activities form a process that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process.  Equipment-specific maintenance requirements and specifications for the SCR systems and storage tanks are contained in the multi-volume set of SCR System Operating and Maintenance Manuals provided by the two SCR system designers, NOELL and Mitsubishi.  Facility maintenance personnel use these manuals and the procedures contained therein as the primary references whenever performing SCR and storage tank inspection, maintenance, test and necessary repair/replacement.  These maintenance/operational procedures are maintained readily available to relevant personnel at the AES Alamitos facility.

Maintenance personnel have received initial formal classroom training prior to initial SCR system startup as discussed in 'Training'.  SCR system equipment was incorporated into the AES Alamitos existing Preventive Maintenance Program.  The facility tracks and documents all manufacturer and regulatory-required maintenance and inspection activities, including a tickle file system for the Preventive Maintenance Program, on AES¿ computerized maintenance tracking system.  The maintenance procedures and requirements for the SCR systems was last reviewed in November 2002.

Equipment routinely inspected includes pumps, lines, vents, detection systems, controls & settings, tank vessels, tank pressure relief valves (PRVs) and settings, system and piping markings, and other elements.  During any related or adjacent maintenance activities (whether or not on the SCR system and tanks), any damage observed during these activities is repaired/replaced as appropriate.

Designated facility personnel perform daily housekeeping inspections, which specifically include the SCR system and tanks. As part of the facility's Clean Water Act/Hazardous Waste (RCRA) compliance program,

all equipment is visually inspected by designated facility personnel a minimum of twice each shift, with the results documented on the RCRA and CWA Inspection Report.  Any damage or malfunction noted is reported and appropriately corrected.  Safety equipment associated with the ammonia systems (eye wash/shower, respirator protection, etc.) is also routinely inspected as part of the facility's ongoing existing occupational safety programs.


COMPLIANCE AUDITS
To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, AES Alamitos periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the risk management and accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years.  This audit reviews each of the USEPA-required prevention program elements to ensure that they are up-to-date and are being implemented and will help identify problem areas and if necessary take corrective actions.  Compliance audits are conducted by a team lead by AES Corporation corporate compliance personnel assisted by an outside compliance auditing consultant.  AES Alamitos personnel (including the Environmental Manager) also participate in the audit.  An RMP compliance audit checklist is used during the audit.  The last audit (which included the RMP) was performed the end of 2003 with the audit report issued to facility management for development and implementation of any corrective action on 12/31/2003.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.


INCIDENT INVESTIGATION
A primary tool used by AES Alamitos to identify the contributing factor(s) responsible for accidents, incidents, occupational illnesses, or unusual hazardous events is a thorough and properly completed incident/accident investigation.  The incident investigation will at

tempt to focus on root causes or contributing factors associated with an accident or incident.  From these findings, corrective action will be initiated as necessary to reduce the potential for recurrence.  The incident investigation procedures used are an existing, integral part of the AES Alamitos Safety and Injury and Illness Prevention Program. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts, identify causal factors and root causes, then develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  AES Alamitos¿ accident investigation procedure was last revised November 2002.

The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent recurrence, and forwards these results to management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation teams findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so reports can be reviewed during future RMPs, PHAs and PHA revalidation.

Although all industrial accidents or injuries are formally investigated as part of the facility¿s ongoing safety program, specific to the aqueous ammonia handled in the SCR systems and associated storage tanks, AES Alamitos will make additional investigative efforts when investigate incident which would meet, or could have resulted in, an accident  meeting the `RMP reportable 5-year accident criteria¿ (on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place).  Should an RMP-reportable accident occur in the future, AES Alamitos will revise the RMP to include information about the accident within six months of the accident¿s occurrence, an

d revise the incident investigation information in the RMP.  Specifically, AES Alamitos will revise (1) the date of investigation to reflect the date of the investigation of the accident being included in the five year history; and (2) the expected date of completion of any changes due to that accident investigation, and submit a corrected RMP within six months of the date of the accident.  As stated previously, there have been no accidents meeting this threshold since SCRs have been in use at AES Alamitos.  There have been no recordable accidents of any kind involving the SCR system.

The storage facility for Units 5 and 6 includes a single 20,000-gallon, double-walled underground tank system with three aqueous ammonia supply pumps, piping, valves, instrumentation, controls, and electrical. The aqueous ammonia storage tank system consists of a 50 psig primary horizontal pressure vessel (designed and manufactured in accordance with ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code Section VIII) enclosed within a secondary containment tank (designed and manufactured in accordance with UL Standard 58) which is externally clad with fiberglass reinforced polyester resin (in accordance with UL Standard 1746). The fiberglass resin was tested after delivery to ensure its integrity and corrosion inhibiting capability.

The primary vessel is equipped with a vacuum breaker with flame arrester, and a large capacity relief valve set at 50 psig and vented to the atmosphere 12 feet above grade. The flame arrester minimizes the potential for an open flame to be drawn into the main tank. The secondary containment tank is also vented to the atmosphere 12 feet above grade through a dryer canister in parallel with a conservation pressure vent. This arrangement prevents breathing in moisture while allowing a bypass path to prevent pressure build up in the secondary containment.

A liquid leak detection system is provided for the underground storage tank with leak detector elements installed in the secondary containment compartment (two elements), supply pump columns (one element each), safety relief valve discharge (one element), and underground piping secondary containment (one element). The elements are wired to a local leak monitor and alarm panel which will also annunciate to control room operators via the plant distributed control system (DCS). Detection of liquid in the underground piping secondary containment will trip the supply pumps.

INTRODUCTION

GENERAL RESUBMITTAL BACKGROUND
This June 2004 Risk Management Plan (RMP) is a 5-year resubmittal of the AES Alamitos, LLC¿s RMP (originally filed in June 1999 for the Units 5&6 SCR system, with an update prepared in October 2001 (with a revised version in November 2002) to reflect the two new SCR systems for Units 1 ¿ 4).  The RMP was prepared in compliance of both the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements. This resubmittal includes an updated narrative description (in this Executive Summary) of the AES Alamitos aqueous ammonia accident prevention program, the additional data elements required by the April 2004 USEPA revised RMP regulations, and represents a thorough review of operating and maintenance procedures, and a review of the process hazard analyses previously conducted.  

Two physical changes to the system were made after the original 1999 submittal: 1) Prior to October 2001, the 7,500 gallon vertical day tank serving the demineralizer system was permanently placed out of service and completely isolated from the Units 5&6 SCR ammonia system (this change was reflected in the November 2002 RMP submittal), and 2) a small ammonia line now feeds a small amount of ammonia (on manual demand) to the boiler feed water system at Units 1&2 and 3&4 ¿ replacing the use of 55-gallon drums of 29.4% aqueous ammonia.  As part of the 2004 RMP resubmittal effort, a Hazard and Operability (HazOp) Study was performed on the two system changes.  There were no previously unidentified consequences or prevention program activities/recommendations resulting from this HazOp. 

As documented in the Offsite Consequence Analysis prepared for the 2001/2002 RMP revision, these modifications at the facility did not result in

an increase of the offsite consequence analysis (OCA) impact distance for ammonia, the hazardous substance of concern, from the original June 1999 RMP.  Therefore, in accordance with AES Alamitos¿ interpretation of USEPA regulations at Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68, at 40 CFR 68.190(b)(4), an RMP update filing with the USEPA was not required in 2002 since the OCA impact distance did not change by more than a factor of two. The California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2745.10 also did not, under that interpretation, require a filing of an updated RMP under the CalARP Program if the OCA impact distance does not change by more than a factor of two unless the process modification is considered significant.

However, in order to maintain a fully accurate and up to date facility RMP, in November 2002 AES Alamitos filed a final revised version of the RMP with the City of Long Beach Department of Health and Human Services (Long Beach CUPA). The final 2002 RMP was only filed with CUPA, and not with the USEPA, since an update was determined not to be required under federal regulations. 

For this 2004 RMP resubmittal, AES Alamitos is preparing and resubmitting the RMP as a single integrated program document which includes all three SCR deNOx systems, and is intended to reset the 5-year resubmittal period to run until June 2009.

RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY COMPONENT

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
AES Alamitos has had an active hazardous materials management and accident prevention program for many years, and emphasizes safety and good management practices in all its activities - conducting all activities in accordance with a detailed, well established Accident Prevention Manual that includes active participation by

management, line and contractor employees. The AES Alamitos facility has an exceptionally strong safety team and committee program, which are actively and visibly supported by facility management. The facility has in place long-established procedures and policies governing hazardous materials and waste handling, spill prevention, environmental compliance and inspections, as well as safety-related policies.  AES Alamitos has a strong commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention (such as SCR system awareness and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the aqueous ammonia SCR systems).  Specific to the SCR system, aboveground storage tanks, and the underground storage tank, a multitude of release prevention design, procedural and operational elements and controls are in place and effective.  As an integral part of the external events analysis for the AES Alamitos Risk Management Program, the facility had conducted a series of Seismic Hazards Analyses that evaluated the stability and integrity of the SCR mechanical systems and related equipment relative to earthquake and related hazards. The recommendations made in these seismic hazards analyses were evaluated and implemented as appropriate.  As detailed in the Maintenance Section of the RMP, AES Alamitos has in place a multi-faceted inspection and maintenance program that includes daily visual inspections and annual maintenance overhauls.
The AES Alamitos policy is to implement reasonable and sustainable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, facility and ammonia vendor personnel (if applicable) will take immediate actions to stop a release, if such actions can be taken immediately and safely.  If not, the facility will evacuate the affected area, contact outside response agencies for assistance, and provide whatever logistical and technical sup

port as deemed necessary by those responding agencies. 

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Alamitos Generation Station, purchased from Southern California Edison (SCE) in 1998 by AES Corporation as part of California's deregulation program, has provided power to Southern California for over 25 years. The AES Alamitos, LLC facility is located 690 North Studebaker Road at the southeastern edge of Long Beach at the Seal Beach border in the City of Long Beach, California. SCE retained the electrical transmission facilities to the north of the current AES Alamitos property (e.g., the switchyards, power distribution lines), as well as property south of Units 5&6.

The AES Alamitos power generating facility burns natural gas in boilers to produce steam. The steam is then used in turbine generators to produce electricity. Currently, the station actively operates six boiler/steam turbine generating units, designated Units 1 through 6. Units I and 2 are rated at 175 MW each, Units 3 and 4 are rated at 320 MW each, and Units 5 and 6 are rated at 480 MW each.

As part of any fossil fuel combustion process, a small amount of nitrogen oxides (NOx) are produced and exhausted to the atmosphere with the other flue gas constituents (mostly nitrogen, carbon dioxide, and water vapor). The amount of NOx that the station is allowed to emit is regulated by the South Coast Air Quality Management District (SCAQMD).  In 1991 ¿ 1992, revised SCAQMD rules required a reduction in allowed NOx emissions and specifically the facility install a NOx emission reduction system on the two largest boilers - Units 5&6.  In 1993, a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) NOx Control System was installed on Units 5 & 6.  In April 2001, AES Alamitos completed installation of two additional SCR systems within the existing boilers of Units 1, 2, 3, and 4.  The installation was part of a December 2000 agreement with SCAQMD.  

The SCR process at Alamitos involves injecting aqueous a

mmonia into the boiler flue gas in the boiler's convective pass. The ammonia/flue gas mixture flows through a catalyst installed between the convective pass and the air preheater. In the presence of the catalyst, the ammonia and NOx react to form nitrogen and water vapor, which exits out the boiler stack. About 87% of the NOx is removed in this manner. The SCR system uses a 29.4% aqueous ammonia solution in the SCR system. The aqueous ammonia is stored in one 20,000-gallon double walled corrosion protected steel underground storage tank for Units 5&6, and three aboveground 20,000-gallon double-walled aboveground and separately-contained carbon steel aqueous ammonia storage tanks for Units 1, 2, 3, and 4.  Since AES Alamitos utilizes aqueous ammonia in amounts over the federal 10,000-pound RMP threshold, the facility and the SCR process are covered under the federal and state Risk Management Prevention program.

OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS ¿ WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS
Several potential release scenarios were evaluated as part of the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA).  The OCA was performed in accordance with USEPA and California CalARP OCA guidance.  The results of this OCA, which included worst case and alternative release scenarios, were considered in the implementation of the prevention program and in facility emergency planning.  The results of the facility's Process Hazard Review was used to determine the most likely (e.g. credible) alternative case release scenario based on operations and system design and maintenance.  The specific details and results of the RMP are maintained by the facility and have been reviewed with local emergency response and planning agencies (primarily the Long Beach CUPA).  The administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each scenario are summarized in this RMP submittal.  Details are integrated within the various program implementation documents (such as operating and ammonia lo

ading procedures) maintained at the facility.  The 1999 and 2001 off-site consequence analysis submitted to Long Beach CUPA (worst case and alternative case release scenarios) were evaluated and found to be still valid and representative, and no change in impact, impacted population or sensitive receptors have been identified.  All data, assumptions and calculations have been verified.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
AES Alamitos¿ SCR systems have had an excellent record of accident prevention since installation.  Over the last 5 years, no accidents meeting the definition of an RMP/CalARP accident have occurred at the facility (on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place).  No accidents of any kind associated with the SCR systems have been recorded.   Should an RMP-reportable accident occur in the future, AES Alamitos will revise the RMP to include information about the accident within six months of the accident¿s occurrence, and revise the incident investigation information in the RMP. Specifically, AES Alamitos will revise (1) the date of investigation to reflect the date of the investigation of the accident being included in the five year history; and (2) the expected date of completion of any changes due to that accident investigation, and submit a corrected RMP within six months of the date of the accident.

AES Alamitos maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  AES Alamitos is a member of the Long Beach Community Awareness and Emergency Response (CAER) program. E PREVENTION PROGRAM
The following is a summary of the accident prevention program (relating to the aqueous ammonia SCR systems) in place at the AES Alamitos facility.  This summary addresses each of the RMP/CalARP elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention plan.

MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR RMP
AES Alamitos has developed an overall management structure/system in order manage various facility operations, controls, and environmental and safety programs ¿ including implementing various elements of the facility¿s Risk Management Program.  A full description of this management structure, including the list of position titles and their general responsibilities, is available for review at the facility.  In summary:

The AES Alamitos General Manager has the overall management responsibility for implementing the RMP for aqueous ammonia facilities at AES Alamitos.  In carrying out this responsibility, the General Manager utilizes the other positions listed below to develop, implement and integrate specific aspects of the Risk Management Program.

Team Leaders report to the General Manager.  The Team Leaders have responsibility for all station operating and maintenance personnel.  The Team Leaders are responsible for ensuring that all equipment is properly monitored and operated and maintained.  The Team Leaders have overall responsibility for implementing the operational aspects of the Risk Management Program.  

Control Room Personnel report to their designated Team Leader.  From their duty stations in the control rooms, Control Room Personnel continuously oversee the operation and monitoring of all station equipment, including providing detailed technical direction to the Plant Technicians for the immediate tasks at hand.  They are responsible for operating and monitoring the Selective Catalytic Reduction system alarms and controls, which are remotely handled (from the control room), and for directing the Plant Technicians to those

ty hazardous waste generators. This training includes the facility's Emergency Response Business Plan ¿ which includes the required elements of a hazardous materials business emergency plan (required by Title 19 CCR) and a  hazardous waste contingency plan (required by Title 22 CCR).  In addition, the facility has procedures that address the maintenance, testing, and inspection of emergency response and ammonia release detection equipment.  The AES Alamitos Emergency Response Business Plan is updated on an annual basis with the new revisions coordinated and reviewed by the Long Beach Fire Department upon issuance. Emergency response and emergency planning issues are also reviewed with the Long Beach CAER group on a periodic ongoing basis.  

The AES Alamitos hazardous materials emergency response program supports and provides for the trained response by designated facility emergency response personnel to incidents involving a wide range of materials. The facility conducts training for such responses. Specifically as it relates to the aqueous ammonia and SCR systems, AES Alamitos personnel are trained to only respond to an aqueous ammonia release if it can be done so safely and without possible risk to safety or health (e.g. minor, incidental spills of low volume). AES Alamitos will immediately contact and rely upon outside response agencies, as well as a pre-contracted, qualified emergency response contractor for all other aqueous ammonia releases.  Primary public response agencies are the Long Beach Fire Department and Los Angeles County Fire Department Hazardous Materials Unit (by automatic aid).  Copies of the SCR systems technical information are available for responding agency use.

The latest emergency plan revision, February 25, 2004 includes the following elements:

¿ List of Emergency Coordinators and Alternates 
¿ Internal and External Notifications and Reporting
¿ Incident Command System (Responsibilities)
¿ Incident/Hazard Evaluation
¿ Containment and Re

moval of Hazardous Waste Release
¿ Scene Restoration and Incident Closure (including use, testing and maintenance of emergency response equipment).
¿ Accident / Incident Investigation
¿ Corrective and Preventive Actions
¿ Plan Revisions and Maintenance
¿ Training

The plan also includes specific information relative to publicity and community or public release of information.  Emergency evacuation procedures are contained in a separate `Emergency Preparedness and Evacuation Plan¿ (revised November 2002).

The AES Alamitos facility¿s hazardous materials emergency response program conforms to the Emergency Response Program requirements in 40 CFR 68.95 and 19 CCR 2545.8.  However, due to the nature and hazard of the material, the significant personal protective equipment and specialized response techniques, and the rarity of any emergency involving the SCR system and storage tank, pursuant to 40 CFR 68.90(b), AES Alamitos is classifying itself as a `Non-Responding Facility¿ specifically as associated with emergency responses involving aqueous ammonia (also reference the USEPA April 2004 RMP Guidance, Chapter 8).  In working with the Greater Long Beach CAER Association, and in coordinating the AES Alamitos business emergency plan submittal with the Long Beach Fire Department, the facility has coordinated with local response agencies to help ensure that they will be prepared to respond to an emergency at the AES Alamitos facility, including procedures to notify emergency responders when there is need for a response.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Based on a detailed review of the previous Process Hazard Analyses for the SCR systems and the recently conducted HazOps for the two system modifications since the original submittal, no specific changes are recommended to improve safety.  The facility will continue to implement it¿s accidental release prevention program and verify conformance to operational, loading, and maintenance procedures.

Plant Technicians report to their designated Team Leader, and receive technical direction from on-duty Control Room Personnel.  They perform local equipment operations at the direction of the respective Control Room Personnel.  The Plant Technicians make a visual inspection of all station equipment twice a shift.  Inspections include checking that all gage readings are normal, no unusual vibration or noise exists, lubrication levels are proper, and no leaks exist.  They are responsible for immediately reporting any abnormalities detected to the Control Room, and will monitor the start up of the Selective Catalytic Reduction system air blowers, pumps, piping and other equipment.  During aqueous ammonia deliveries, Control Room Personnel will dispatch one or more Plant Technicians to the aqueous ammonia truck at the appropriate storage tank location. The Plant Technician will be equipped with the appropriate personal protective equipment and two-way communication.  They verify the content of the delivery truck, the proper fill connections, valving, and monitors the area until delivery is complete.  In the event of an aqueous ammonia release, the Plant Technician would contact the Control Room immediately. 

Environmental Manager is responsible for the facility safety and environmental issues, and for overall RMP regulatory compliance and administration.  The Environmental Manager ensures that all station safety and environmental procedures are followed, coordinates all station safety and environmental training, and maintains records relating to all station safety and environmental issues.  The Environmental Manager is also designated as the Risk Management Program Coordinator.

The Engineer Support Person has the responsibility of technical review of the various projects occurring at the station.  This college degreed individual is responsible in determining the work scope of the proper installation of station modific

ations.  The Engineer Support Person will work with other departments within the station and throughout AES to ensure proper operation of existing station systems.  The Engineer Support Person is responsible for ensuring that the aqueous ammonia facility and equipment is designed, fabricated, and installed in accordance with applicable codes and regulations, that field construction meets all applicable codes and regulations, and for providing training and initial startup support to AES Alamitos facility personnel.  Finally, the Engineer Support Person is responsible for providing the station with a system description, equipment manuals and data, prints, and procedures of sufficient detail to allow the station to assume responsibility for the operation and maintenance of the aqueous ammonia facility and equipment for its lifetime, commencing at the conclusion of initial start-up activities.


PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION
AES Alamitos facility keeps on file a variety of technical documents that are used to help design and maintain safe operation of the aqueous ammonia SCR system.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  Facility maintenance and engineering personnel within the facility are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.   Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs).  As part of the SCR system design documents, this information was supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns.  As part of the manufacturer¿s SCR system design documentation on file at the facility, documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g. pressure, flow rate, temperature, etc.) are maintained.  The facility ensures that the process is maintained within these limi

ts using process controls, and monitoring instruments, trained personnel, and manual and automated shutdown systems.

The AES Alamitos facility maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the SCR system (including ammonia storage).  The information includes materials of construction, design pressure, temperature ratings, and electrical ratings of equipment. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides the basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features are not compromised.

Summary System Descriptions

Units 1 through 4
AES uses a 29.4 percent aqueous ammonia solution for the SCR systems serving Units 1-4. Aqueous ammonia is stored in three 20,000-gallon, double-walled, aboveground, and separately contained carbon steel ammonia storage tanks. The storage tanks are ASME-registered U-stamped pressure vessels designed for ammonia service. To minimize potential ammonia leakage, the tanks utilize a double-wall design. The inter-wall space is isolated from the main storage space and can be drained independent of the main storage area. The ammonia supply of the boiler SCR units is taken from these storage tanks.

Units 1 and 2 utilize one tank (located south of Unit 1) and Units 3 and 4 utilize two tanks (located south of Unit 3). The proposed tanks are horizontal, and have a nominal capacity of 20,000 U.S. gallons. The tanks are capable of withstanding pressures of 25 pounds per square inch gage (psig), which is designed for the worst-case ambient temperature condition of 125 degrees Fahrenheit. 

Each storage tank is placed within a concrete berm that is between 645.7-649.6 square feet in area. The berms have design capacities of 110 percent of the tank volume, which accounts for 6.5 inches (over 24 hours) of cumulative rainfall for a 25-year frequency storm.

The piping system for aqueous ammonia is Schedule 80 Grade 316 stainless Steel with welded fittings in all areas by the metering pump, liquid injector area, and ammonia storage area.  The underground containment pipe is compression fitting 4 PVC schedule 80.  Power Piping Code ANSI B31.1 recommends piping hanger spans of 8 1/2 feet for 1 1/2 diameter pipe size (water service) at 1g-loads. The corresponding maximum weight stress level from Table 121.5 of the ANSI B31.1 Code, 1989 edition, is 2300 psi. Since the seismic g-load for the subject area is .3g in any horizontal direction, the combined load is only .42g in the horizontal direction. Therefore, the allowable seismic span is estimated to be 200 feet (using (1.0g/0.42g) x 8.5 feet = 20 feet). The seismic span for the aqueous ammonia piping is less than 10 feet in every case. In addition, the pressure stress is negligible since the maximum aqueous ammonia pressure is only 90 psi. Consequently, the seismic design of the aqueous ammonia piping is well within ANSI B31.1 l

imits.

The ammonia storage tanks are filled via vendor tanker truck deliveries scheduled at regular intervals based upon ammonia consumption.  Truck supply hoses are connected to a loading bulkhead. Transfer pumps, hose purge equipment, and loading controls are provided on the tanker truck itself.  A two-inch fill line and a two-inch vapor return line are routed from the primary vessel through block valves to quick connect type couplings for truck unloading. The fill line allows the transfer of aqueous ammonia from the delivery truck to the tank, while the vapor return line allows the displaced ammonia vapors from the tank to be returned to the truck. The fill and vapor return piping are securely anchored at the truck unloading station.  The unloading station is within the spill containment barrier that runs along the perimeter of the tank.  The tank has a visual level gauge in the vicinity of the loading station to assist the unloading truck operator and to prevent overfilling. A ground cable is provided for connection to the unloading truck. Safety eyewash/shower combinations are provided at the storage tank and adjacent to the metering pump skid for each unit.  Upon completion of filling operations, all lines are purged with compressed air prior to being disconnected.

An ammonia vapor detector system is provided with four ammonia detectors installed above grade on the perimeter of each storage tank facility with additional detectors located around the metering pumps.  The detectors are wired to a local ammonia monitor and alarm panel which will also annunciate to control room operators via the plant DCS.  A safety shower is available in the tank areas, and at each metering pump skid.
